Award.AwardTitle: Hydrogen isotope response of algal lipids to variable nutrient concentrations in Swiss lakes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. S. Nemiah Ladd has been granted an NSF Earth Sciences postdoctoral fellowship to study how fossilized algal remains record nutrient pollution. This fellowship will allow an early career American scientist to carry out a research project at Eawag, the Swiss Federal Institute of Aquatic Science and Technology. Eutrophication (nutrient pollution of lakes and other aquatic ecosystems) is commonly caused by fertilizers and detergents. It can result in harmful algal blooms and widespread fish death, and reduces the economic and aesthetic value of water bodies. The Swiss government has been especially proactive about reducing the causes of eutrophication and remediating polluted lakes. However, despite concerted efforts over the past thirty-five years, a range of nutrient concentrations persists among lakes in the central Swiss plateau. This project will develop a novel tool to reconstruct past nutrient levels in lakes from molecular algal fossils in lake sediment. It will also refine the use of existing proxies of past climate, which are based on the same sedimentary markers. During her fellowship, Dr. Ladd will promote the education of young scientists from developing countries by collaborating with the Eawag Partnership Program (EPP) to create a mentoring program to support visiting graduate students. Because EPP fellows will take newly honed skills back to their local institutions, and use them to address local problems, support of the EPP fellowship program will more broadly impact the advancement of science in Africa and Asia, and facilitate the study of a range of environmental, economic, and social issues related to water use and quality throughout the developing world.

Lipids produced by algae are resistant to degradation and can persist unchanged in sediment for millions of years. They typically record the hydrogen isotope composition of the water in which the algae grew, which is controlled by climatic variables such as temperature, rainfall, and atmospheric circulation patterns. Algal lipids have therefore been developed as a useful proxy for past climate. However, several other variables can influence the isotopic composition of algal lipids. Of particular importance for this project, in laboratory studies hydrogen isotope fractionation in marine algae is highly sensitive to nutrient availability. By measuring isotope fractionation in algal lipids from living algae, falling particles, and surface sediment in Swiss lakes with variable phosphate concentrations, this project will for the first time establish whether nutrient availability and growth rate affect hydrogen isotope fractionation in natural settings, and for freshwater algae. In the second phase of this work, the environmental histories of different lakes will be reconstructed by applying the results of the calibration study to sediment cores. Determining the natural variability among lakes with identical climate histories will permit a more complete assessment of ongoing pollution remediation strategies.

This award was supported with funding from the Office of International and Integrative Activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Eutrophication (nutrient pollution of lakes and other aquatic ecosystems) is commonly caused by fertilizers and detergents. It can result in harmful algal blooms and widespread fish death, and reduces the economic and aesthetic value of water bodies. This project sought to develop sedimentary proxies of past eutrophication and algal productivity, by studying the impact of elevated phosphorus availability on lipid distributions and isotope composition in molecules produced by algae growing in ten lakes in central Switzerland with different histories of nutrient loading. These lake systems were an ideal natural laboratory in which to conduct the investigation because the Swiss government has been especially proactive about reducing the causes of eutrophication and remediating polluted lakes, and has collected detailed monitoring information of the lakes over the past several decades. However, despite concerted efforts over the past thirty-five years, a range of nutrient concentrations persists among the studied lakes.

The results of this project demonstrated that different lipid biomarkers produced by algal have opposing hydrogen isotope responses to phosphorus loading. Hydrogen isotopes of the sterol brassicasterol diverge more from lake water isotopes as total phosphorus increases. On the other hand, hydrogen isotopes of phytol, the side-chain of chlorophyll molecules, get more similar to water isotopes as total phosphorus increases. The contrasting response to nutrient availability is consistent with the results of laboratory cultures, and is most likely due to biochemical changes within the cell as nutrient levels increase. These results suggest that hydrogen isotopes of the two lipids can be measured simultaneously back through time to reconstruct past growth conditions, a valuable new tool for studying the eutrophication histories of lakes.

An additional component of the project reconstructed changes in hydrogen isotope fractionation in fatty acids over the past two centuries in Lake Baldegg, a lake that experienced changes in total phosphorus concentrations of more than 500 mg per cubic meter during the 20th century. Well-documented changes in total phosphorus, diatom species assemblages, and the oxygen isotopes of carbonates that precipitated within the lake made Lake Baldegg a promising system in which to test the influence of competing variables on the hydrogen isotope composition of algal lipid biomarkers. Our results demonstrated that at total phosphorus levels below 200 mg per cubic meter, the fatty acid hydrogen isotopes were consistent with water isotope values predicted by the oxygen isotopes of carbonates, suggesting that hydrogen isotopes of this generic lipid can be used as a tracer of past hydrology is most natural systems. However, during severe eutrophication above 200 mg P per cubic meter, fatty acid hydrogen isotopes decouple from water isotopes, most likely due to changes in the source of sedimentary fatty acids as the nutrient loading led to wide-spread changes in the algal community.

Hydrogen isotopes of lipids have applications to multiple disciplines, and our results have contributed to other topics beyond developing a proxy for past eutrophication. We combined measurements of lipid hydrogen isotopes with algal species distributions, and demonstrated the potential to use lipid distributions and their hydrogen isotopes as a proxy for algal community structure. Additionally, measurements of leaf waxes from the surface sediments in our lake samples were combined with leaf wax hydrogen isotopes from living plants, soils, and aerosols collected in central Switzerland. Together, these data demonstrate the role wind plays in bringing leaf waxes from plants to lake sediments. Leaf waxes are some of the most commonly used molecular fossils, and constraining their transport history is important for using them to address questions pertaining to past hydrology and ecosystem function.

Lipid hydrogen isotopes change in response to a complex set of variables, but have the advantage of producing relatively large signals compared to other isotope systems. The environmental information that is gained from analyzing lipid hydrogen isotopes is in many ways still being elucidated, but rigorous field tests, such as the one completed here in Swiss lakes, are laying the foundation for a new toolkit that can be applied to a diverse range of questions, ranging from nutrient pollution to ecology to hydrology. This project has laid the foundation for new proxies of past environmental change and modern algal ecology, and has spurred new studies in both the United States and Switzerland to further develop and validate these tools.
